subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary in lexical sets?
msgSnippet: ... Yes, but there are so many ASCII proposals right now that it is hard for me to keep them straight, especially with the vowel + letter. Plus, I want to keep
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
> > While I am working on a QuikScript dictionary, I keep wanting a system
> > that will represent phonemes rather than sounds. Is it possible to
> > create a useful dictionary with lexical sets and letters?
>
> There are QS letters (or letter + R pairs) for all the lexical sets.
> Just use an ASCII transcription of them, either QS-SAMPA or whichever
> else you please. It's just a matter of keeping straight whether
> your symbols are being used phonemically or phonetically.
>

Yes, but there are so many ASCII proposals right now that it is hard for
me to keep them straight, especially with the vowel + letter. Plus, I
want to keep STRUT distinct from /y/ for now, and there is no QS letter
for STRUT.

My dictionary lists words like cure as [kyU@r]. It seems that I don't
want the [@], but I won't know for sure until later. So at this point I
want a shorthand for k + CURE. (Or k + y + CURE, so that later I can
decide what y + CURE equals.)

Last, the dictionary might be more useful for others later if I use
Lexical sets.

I guess I also should have said that the dictionary need not spell out
the lexical sets; a letter or number or whatever can stand for each
lexical set, but it would help to think in terms of lexical sets right.

So does it make sense to have the dictionary look something like:

cure cP

Where the capital letter P represents the CURE lexical sets?

I'm thinking that when the dictionary is done, I can put a key at the
top, something like:

p = CURE
D = NURSE

Paul
